keyTakeAways: George Santos, a former US Representative from New York, was released from prison on October 19, 2025, after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for wire fraud and identity theft.
Santos admitted to stealing the identities of 11 people, including family members, and misrepresented his biography during the 2022 congressional campaign.
During his 84 days in federal prison, Santos described prison conditions as dehumanizing, citing mold, broken air conditioning, and shoddy construction in the FCI Fairton facility.
Santos has stated he is no longer interested in running for office and is instead dedicating his life to prison reform, which he says is a 'new mission' and a way to redeem himself.
He has spoken with President Trump about his prison reform goals and expressed a desire to work with the administration to improve the prison system.

The Bureau of Prisons declined to comment on Santos' allegations due to the ongoing government shutdown, and no official response has been provided from FCI Fairton regarding the conditions he described.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former US Representative George Santos, who was removed from Congress in 2023 following an ethics scandal and later sentenced to seven years in federal prison for wire fraud and identity theft, has been released after President Donald Trump commuted his sentence. During his 84-day incarceration at FCI Fairton, Santos described poor prison conditions, including mold, broken air conditioning, and substandard construction, calling the system 'broken' and 'dehumanizing'. Now free, Santos has declared a new mission: prison reform, stating he is no longer interested in politics and is dedicated to improving the prison system. He has communicated with President Trump about this mission and has published reflections on The South Shore Press. However, no official response has been given by the Bureau of Prisons or FCI Fairton regarding his claims of mistreatment.
title: George Santos has a newfound mission: prison reform
